lesson.title: Vehicle Dynamics
lesson.summary: Learn how flying vehicles move in one and two dimensions by understanding how propellers create forces and moments which cause accelerations and rotations.

atoms.title: Nd787 C3 L1 00 Sebastian V1
L01 01 Intro V2

atoms.text: # Lesson Outline In this lesson you will learn about the physics which underlies motion in one and two dimensions. We will cover 3D dynamics in the fourth lesson of this course. #### Part 1 - Basic (1D) Quadrotor Physics We're going to go *quickly* through this section. We assume you've taken basic physics before and this is mostly a review. * Definition of Force * Forces on a Quadrotor: **gravity / weight**, **thrusts**, **drag** (which we won't be modeling) * Translational Equilibrium / Hover * Rotational Equilibrium * Definition of Moment / Torque * Rotor Physics: F = k_f \omega^2 and M = k_m \omega^2 * F = m a and F_z = m \ddot{z} * \tau = I \alpha and M_z = I_z \ddot{\psi} * `Programming Exercise: Coaxial Copter Dynamics` #### Part 2 - Quadrotor Math: Second Order Systems This will be a brief introduction to some of the math and programming we use to keep track of the **state** of flying vehicles. * `Programming Exercise: Tracking Changes to State` * Second order systems / double integrated systems * Using vectors to store state #### Part 3 - Dynamics of Controlled Quadrotors (2D) Now we will allow the vehicle to move in two dimensions. This part is meant to be a quick review of the trigonometry and physics required for 2D motion. * Decomposing thrust vectors (review of trig: \sin and \cos ) * Calculating moments: \tau = d_\text{perp} \times F * Converting propeller rotations to Forces and Moments * `Programming Exercise: 2D Controlled Quad`

atoms.title: C3 C1 L2 Forces On Quad V3

atoms.text:
## Quadrotor Intuition

Imagine looking at a quadrotor from the side. What happens when the thrust from the left rotors is bigger than the thrust from the right? What happens when they're equal?

You probably already have a good intuitive sense for how some of this control works.

complex_prompt.text:
The images above show three quadrotors with different-sized forces coming from the left and right propellers.

Match the quadrotor (A, B, or C) to the written description of how it will **rotate**.

atoms.title: C3 C1 L3 Trans Equal V1

atoms.caption: This *monorotor* is currently hovering in place.

question.prompt: The *monorotor* shown above is currently hovering in place. What can you say about the value of F_\text{thrust}?
Which of the following is the **correct** expression for the **mass** of this vehicle?
If a monorotor's propellor were providing the thrust upwards that you just identified, what kind of equilibrium would the monorotor be in?

atoms.title: C3 C1 L4 Rot Equal V1

atoms.text: The monorotor from [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P3fM6VwXXFM) is pretty amazing! Notice how the body of the vehicle rotates in the opposite direction of the rotor.

atoms.title: C3 C1 L5 Rot Equal 2 V2
C3 C1 L6 Rotor Physics V2

atoms.text: ## Measuring k_F and k_M The values for k_F and k_M are generally found empirically. We mount the motor and propeller on a load cell and measure the force and moment for different motor speeds. The graph below shows a simulation of the data you might get from such an experiment.

question.prompt: Based on the Force vs omega graph shown above, what is k_F for this propeller?
If you double the rotation speed of a rotor, how does the thrust change?

atoms.title: L01 07 Unbalanced Forces V1
C3 C1 L8 Fma V1

question.prompt: What thrust would a **2.2 kg monorotor** need in order to accelerate upwards at -4.0 m / s^2 (remember, z is positive downwards)?

atoms.title: C3 C1 L9 Unbalanced Movements V3

atoms.caption: When viewed from above, rotor 1 (on top) spins CW with \omega_1. Rotor 2 (bottom) spins CCW with \omega_2.

question.prompt: Look at the "flying car" shown above. It's supported by two rotors spinning in opposite directions. If rotor 1 (top) spins faster than rotor 2, in which direction will the body of the vehicle experience angular acceleration?

atoms.text: | Quantity | Value | |:--------:|:-----:| | m | 1.0 | | I_z | 2.0 | | k_F | 0.1 | | k_M | 0.2 | | \omega_1 | 10.0 | | \omega_2 | 8.0 | Consider a coaxial copter with the above quantities (all values are given in standard units). What will be the resulting linear acceleration \ddot{z}? What about rotational acceleration \ddot{\psi}?

question.prompt: What will the resulting \ddot{z} be for the system described above? Z is positive down.
What will the resulting \ddot{\psi} be for the system described above? CW rotations are positive.

atoms.title: AB L1 01 Coaxial Copter Dynamics Explained

atoms.text:
In the video (from minute 1:41 to 1:48) you will notice that the equations of omega_1, omega_2 are different from the Solutions. Please refer to the correct ones reported on the Solutions, which we post here below:

omega_1 = math.sqrt(term_1 - term_2)

omega_2 = math.sqrt(term_1 + term_2)

atoms.title: AB L1 02 Tracking Changes To State

atoms.text:
The state of our system in the 1D space is currently defined by:

X = (z, psi, z_dot, psi_dot)

atoms.title: C3 C1 L13 2nd Order Of Systems V2

question.prompt: For the 1D case, we needed to keep track of four variables (`self.z`, `self.psi`, `self.z_dot`, `self.psi_dot`) to track the state of the vehicle AND we needed to update these variables with 4 equations. How many variables / equations do we need to keep track of state in 3D?

atoms.title: AB L1 03 Compact Representations Of State
C3 C1 L15 Motion In 2D Dimensions V1
C3 C1 L16 Decomposing Thrust V2

atoms.text: In the image above, the thrusts from the two propellers have been combined into a single F_{\text{thrust}}. For the following questions assume the quantities shown above have the following values (in standard units): | Quantity | Value | | :-----: | :-----: | | m | 10 | | F_{\text{thrust}} | 120 | | \phi | 30^{\circ} |

question.prompt: Which of the following expressions gives the total force in the horizontal y direction F_y for this vehicle?
What will be the resulting acceleration in the y direction \ddot{y}?

atoms.title: C3 C1 L17 Calculating Moments V2

atoms.text: Consider the quadrotor shown above. The length of each arm is L. How would we calculate torques **If** we decided to align the drone's "body" frame with the arms? If that were the case, we'd have something like the following:

question.prompt: For the picture above, which of the following statements about d_{\text{perp,x}} are true?

atoms.text:
As the picture above shows, the perpendicular distance from the propeller to the x-axis is *less than* the length of the propeller arm.

In fact, if you look at the y-axis, the propeller arm, and the vertical line I've added to the diagram, you can start to see a right triangle emerge...
Note that the angle \theta shown in the diagram is **not** meant to represent the yaw of the vehicle (which we represent with \psi). It represents the angle between the rotor arm and the y-axis.

question.prompt: Which of the following expressions gives the correct value of d_{\text{perp,x}} in terms of the arm length L and the angle \theta?

atoms.text:
This means that when this propeller generates a thrust F, it also generates a moment about the x axis:
M_x = F \times L \cos \theta
The coordinate system that we actually use for a quadrotor body frame has the x and y axes pointing half-way between the rotor arms. That means each arm is always at 45 degrees relative to each axis. Since \cos 45^{\circ} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, this means:
M_x = \frac{F \times L}{\sqrt{2}}
So when you see \sqrt{2} floating around in quadrotor math, this often explains why. Sometimes we will also use lower l = L / \sqrt{2} to represent perpendicular distance.

concepts.title: Rotation Rates to Moments and Thrusts

atoms.title: L01 18 Rotation Rates V3

atoms.text:
## Rotation Rates to Moments and Thrusts


```
    def get_thrust_and_moment(self):
        """Helper function which calculates and returns the 
        collective thrust and the moment about the X axis"""

        f1 = self.k_f * self.omega_1 ** 2
        f2 = self.k_f * self.omega_2 ** 2
        
        # c is often used to indicate "collective" thrust
        c = f1 + f2
        
        M_x = (f1 - f2) * self.l
        return c, M_x
```

In the exercise below you'll probably want to use this function as you implement three new methods in the `Drone2D` class.

atoms.title: L01 19 Controlling 2D Quad V1
